instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKLT_PWM: What is BKLT_PWM? BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKLT_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message:
I have this 17" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no backlight. 
what i've done so far

backlight fuse test good with 12.3v on both sides
checked for voltage a lvds connector pins 38,39,40 i get 38.2v
checked pin 4 i get 3.2v 
checked pin 2-3 i get 3.1v
i have replaced both lcd and cable with known tested components

it is posting video just no backlight. not really sure what I'm missing. any ideas?
​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: 38V means there is no load on the bus. Check connector/cable/LCD. You can connect a 15" assembly for testing if available.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: thanks duke. i did test with anther 17" and 15" using tested cables  with same result. the only think i have left to try is change the connector. i will try and report back.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: Just measure continuity to the end of a separate LCD cable

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: yes i have continuity to the end of a lcd cable .001. multimeter beeps when i have continuity.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: Voltage on <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>, LCD must be connected.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message:
voltage on <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> ON <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> is 3.11v
voltage on <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> ON <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> IS 0.0V
voltage on <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> ON <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> IS 0.0V

i find it interesting that there is voltage on <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> but not on <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> so i checked for continuity and everything seems ok.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message:
If it is on <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> it must be on <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>, it is a resistor divider and one cannot work without the other. It does mean that I cannot rely on your measurements though cause they are obviously wrong.
But <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> is not there if you measured correctly. Do a PRAM reset and see if it comes on. May need to do it a few times and power off and boot into OSX. Then try to turn up the brightness on the keyboard.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: i've measured them a couple times because thats what i thought too. and still same results. but in the mean time i decided to check for short to ground on <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> and sure enough it was grounded. i traced it back to <RESISTOR>R9693</RESISTOR> removed the resistor and sure enough short to ground on pin1 of <RESISTOR>R9693</RESISTOR>. I'm guessing this means <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> has an issue.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: Measure on <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> if there is a short to GND. If yes then remove it and see on which side it is.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: i did remove the <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and the short to ground is on the pin 2 <SIGNAL>LVDS_BLK_PWM_RC</SIGNAL>. Which if I'm correct means i have to change <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>. ill report back soon as i get that changed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: ok. i got the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> changed with no more short to ground on <SIGNAL>LVDS_BLK_PWM_RC</SIGNAL>,  but still no voltage on it and no voltage on either side of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> which i believe comes from <RESISTOR>R9693</RESISTOR> which has no voltage either. so would that be an smc issue?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and connect pin 2 to <CAPACITOR>C9711</CAPACITOR>. This puts 3V on the PWM input and LCD will always be on full brightness. Else you need to change the MUX which is not worth the hassle.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: i did as asked with running a wire and it worked. So what I'm wondering is could i run a wire from a 3.3v sleep line and have the screen turn off during sleep mode?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: Uhm backlight should go off in sleep, does it stay on? Does it even really go to sleep, light on front pulsing? I bet J4800 not connected.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message:
i just miss read what u said, thought the backlight would always be on when the machine is on or in sleep. but i see now its just the screen brightness will always be at highest.
right now I'm just testing for backlight out of the system, i will put the board back in the case and test then report back.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight issue
threads.message: It does go to sleep but screen brightness is not adjustable which I'm ok with. Hopefully it doesn't kill the battery too fast lol.
